conclusion: To determine at which moment objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The graph shows the velocity (v) of objects A and B over time (t).
The area under each curve represents the displacement of each object.
At t = 0, both objects start from the same location.
At t = t_1, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t = t_2, object A's velocity decreases to zero, while object B's velocity is still positive.
At t = t_3, object A's velocity becomes negative, indicating it is moving in the opposite direction.
At t = t_4, object B's velocity decreases to zero.
The displacement of each object at any time t is the area under the respective velocity-time curve up to that time.

premise: The displacement of each object at any time t is the area under the respective velocity-time curve up to that time.
conclusion: To find when the objects are farthest apart, we need to compare the areas under the curves for both objects.

premise: From t = 0 to t = t_2, object A is moving forward and then stops, while object B continues moving forward.
conclusion: The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the curves is the greatest.

premise: From t = t_2 to t = t_3, object A starts moving backward, while object B continues moving forward.
conclusion: The maximum separation occurs at t = t_3, where the area under object B's curve is the largest compared to the area under object A's curve.

premise: The maximum separation occurs at t = t_3, where the area under object B's curve is the largest compared to the area under object A's curve.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at t = t_3.
